journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Free vibration of rotating axially functionally graded tapered beams

article-meta.aff: 1School of Civil Engineering, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran
2Centre of Numerical Methods in Engineering, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran
3Center of Excellence for Engineering and Management of Infrastructures, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding author: School of Civil Engineering, University College of Engineering, University of Tehran, PO Box 11365-4563, Tehran, Iran. email: shahba@alumni.ut.ac.ir; ah.shahba@gmail.com

abstract.p: In this article, free vibration characteristics of rotating axially functionally graded tapered beams with six different boundary conditions are studied through a finite-element approach. The beam element employed in this study is a two-noded element whose shape functions are obtained in terms of special functions namely basic displacement functions. Application of this beam element provides good results as the shape functions take the effects of variable centrifugal force, cross-sectional area, and mechanical properties of the material. In this study, the effects of material non-homogeneity, taper ratio, rotating speed parameter, hub radius, and tip mass are investigated. The results are given in tabular form so that they could be used as a means of comparison for future studies in this field.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: One of the advanced materials used in industry is functionally graded material (FGM). These materials are now used in aerospace installations, mechanical structures, and automobile industries. FGMs are composite materials, which are microscopically non-homogeneous; however, within a macro level, the mechanical properties vary continuously in a desired direction by smoothly varying the volume fractions of the constituents; as a result, the distribution of stress and strain fields would be continuous, as well. Most of the literature on functionally graded beams is devoted to those types of beams with thickness-wise material gradation [1–3], and relatively few studies are conducted for beams with lengthwise material gradation. Elishakoff and his co-workers [4–11] and Aydogdu [12] used a semi-inverse method to study axially functionally graded beams with different boundary conditions. Using a semi-inverse method, the goal of the problem is to find a type of material distribution which satisfies the prescribed displacement. Semi-inverse method provides exact solution to the problem; however, this method cannot be used for those engineering problems in which the material distributions are given and the deformations are required. Huang and Li [13] studied free vibration of non-uniform axial functionally graded (FG) beams by transforming the governing differential equation to Fredholm integral equations. Employing cubic Hermite shape functions, Shahba et al. [14] applied finite-element method to study the free vibration and stability of tapered axially functionally graded beams.

Rotating beams are extensively used in mechanical and aerospace structures such as turbo-machine andturbine blades, helicopter rotor blades, and spacecrafts with flexible appendages [15, 16]. The structural analysis of rotating tapered beams is more complex than the non-rotating ones due to the presence of the centrifugal force and its stiffening effect on the vibration characteristics. An exact solution for the governing differential equation for flapwise motion of tapered rotating beams is not available in the literature due to the presence of variable coefficients introduced by the variable cross-sectional dimensions and centrifugal force. Hence, numerical methods have been employed among which finite-element method [17–22] has gained a more dominant position. For analysis of rotating axially FG tapered beams, the variable mechanical properties add up to the previously mentioned variable coefficients, i.e. cross-sectional area, moment of inertia and centrifugal force. Therefore, application of numerical methods is inevitable.

In this article, we adopt finite-element method to study the free vibration characteristics of rotating axially FG tapered beams. The factor which considerably insures the accuracy of the results predicted by finite-element method is the selection of proper shape functions. More accurate results are determined if the shape functions could efficiently reflect the mechanics of the element. A worthy step towards more accurate shape functions is addressed by Ganguli and his co-workers [19–21]. Using some simplifying assumptions, they proposed shape functions, which could satisfy the static part of the governing differential equation for tapered homogeneous rotating beams. Attarnejad and his co-workers [23–30] have developed a technique for derivation of shape functions from a mechanical point of view. These shape functions are obtained in terms of the so-called basic displacement functions (BDFs). This technique has been used for analysis of several engineering problems including tapered Euler–Bernoulli beams [23–27], tapered Timoshenko beams [28, 29], and non-prismatic curved beams [30].

Here, we extend the formulation given in Attarnejad and Shahba [23] to the analysis of rotating axially FG tapered beams. Moreover, different boundary conditions are considered and the effect of tip mass on the vibration characteristics is investigated. To the authors’ best knowledge, no previous results are available in the literature for rotating axially FG tapered beams. The goals of this article are filling the present gap in the literature and also verifying the competency of the idea of BDFs in the analysis of rotating beams made of axially FG material.
In what follows, first the structural model is outlined and then the finite-element formulation is explained. Afterwards, numerical examples are given and the corresponding conclusions are drawn.

sec.title: 2 STRUCTURAL MODEL
sec.p:
A schematic of a rotating tapered beam is shown in Fig. 1. The beam has a rectangular cross-section with height h and breadth b. The beam is attached to a rigid hub with radius R rotating about Z axis with a constant angular speed Ω. Fig. 1
Coordinate system and the rotating tapered beam cross-sectional dimensions

sec.title: 2.1 Strain and kinetic energies
sec.p: Following the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory, the strain energy of the rotating axially FG tapered beam element could be written as (1) where x is longitudinal coordinate along beam element, L the length of beam element, w the transverse displacement, E and I the modulus of elasticity andarea moment of inertia, respectively, which are functions of x to account for the material gradation and variable cross-section, respectively. The centrifugal force T at x within the ith element is given by[23] (2) in which N is the total numbers of beam elements, x¯j the location of the left node of the jth element, as shown in Fig. 1, and ρ and A the mass density and cross-sectional area, respectively. Following the principle of virtual work [31], the static part of the governing differential for flapwise deformation of rotating axially FG tapered beams is derived from equation (1) as
Moreover, the kinetic energy of the beam element could be written as
where an over dot represents differentiation with respect to time t.

sec.title: 3 FINITE-ELEMENT FORMULATION
sec.p:
It is observed from equation (3) that the governing differential equation cannot be easily solved due to the presence of the variable coefficients. Here, we follow a finite-element approach to solve this problem. Consider a two-noded beam element with two degrees of freedom per node, as depicted in Fig. 2. Based on finite-element method, the transverse displacement could be written in terms of the nodal degrees of freedom using shape functions as Fig. 2
Positive sign convention for nodal degrees of freedom

in which N and d are vectors containing shape functions and nodal degrees of freedom. In this article, we take advantage of the shape functions proposed by Attarnejad and Shahba [23], since they capture the effects of varying cross-sectional area, mechanical properties of the material and centrifugal force. The shape functions show a good rate of convergence in free vibration analysis. The shape functions are given as (6) where b={bv1bθ1bv2bθ2}T is the vector containing BDFs. G is a 4×4 matrix containing the nodal stiffness matrices of the left and right nodes. The definition and computation of BDFs and the process of derivation of shape functions in terms of BDFs are briefly given in Appendix.
Using equation (5), equations (1) and (4) could be expressed in matrix form as
in which K and M are, respectively, the stiffness and consistent mass matrices given by

It is worth noting that the first and second integrals of the right-hand side of equation (8a) are mostly known as flexural and geometric stiffness matrices. Summing up the energies of the beam elements, the Lagrangian functional is obtained as
Substituting equation (9) into the Lagrange’s equation
the free vibration motion is derived as

where D is the generalized displacement vector of the structure, Kg and Mg the global stiffness and mass matrices, respectively, obtained through the standard finite-element assembling procedure. Assuming a sinusoidal variation for D, equation (11) is rewritten as
Solving the generalized eigenvalue problem in equation (12), the natural frequencies ω and the associated mode shapes ϕ are calculated.

sec.title: 4 NUMERICAL EXAMPLES
sec.p: In this section, numerical examples are carried out to investigate the effects of several parameters in the free vibration of rotating axially FG tapered beam.
It is assumed that the cross-sectional area and moment of inertia vary respectively in accordance with

where x¯ is the longitudinal coordinate along thewhole beam, l the length of whole beam, c the taper ratio, A0 and I0, respectively, the values of cross-sectional area and moment of inertia at the root, i.e. x¯=0, and m an arbitrary integer, here either 1 or 2. The practical applications of beams with such variations of cross-sectional area and moment of inertia are well illustrated in Fig. 2 of Banerjee and Williams [32]. It can be readily verified that the beam would be uniform if c is set to zero and it would taper to a point, a theoretical limit, if c equals unity.

In this article, six different boundary conditions are considered and illustrated in Fig. 3. For the purpose of description of boundary conditions, a notation will be adopted as follows. The symbolism C, P, F, and G will identify the clamped, pinned, free, and guided boundary conditions, respectively. For example, C–F denotes a clamped boundary condition at x¯=0 and a free one at x¯=l. Fig. 3
Illustration of different boundary conditions: (a) clamped–clamped; (b) pinned–clamped; (c) clamped–pinned; (d) pinned–pinned; (e) clamped–free; (f) pinned–free
In order to facilitate the presentation of results, the following dimensionless parameters are introduced
In the above dimensionless parameters, M is the tip mass and the subscript z refers to the material properties of zirconia which will be given in section 4.1.

sec.title: 4.1 Convergence study
sec.p: It is essential to check the convergence rate of the present element in free vibration analysis. For this purpose, consider a rotating axially FG tapered beam with m=1, δ=0, c=0.8, η=10, and C–F boundary conditions. FGM is assumed to be made of aluminum and zirconia with the following properties
The material properties are assumed to vary along the beam axis with a power law relation [33]

in which n is the material non-homogeneity parameter, λ a typical material property, e.g. E and ρ and the subscripts a and z refer to the values of the parameter for aluminum and zirconia, respectively. The variation of the modulus of elasticity is depicted for a unit length beam in Fig. 4 for different values of n. It is obvious that the percentage content of zirconia increases as n increases towardsinfinity. It is recommended [33] that n varies in the range of 1/3≤n≤3 as any value out of this range would result into a FG material with too high percentage of one of the constituents, here zirconia. Fig. 4
Variation of Young’s modulus with respect to different n values

For the purpose of convergence study, n is set to 2. Figure 5 compares the convergence of the present and conventional elements with respect to different numbers of elements in determination of the first four natural frequency parameters (μ=ωρzA0l4EzI0). For the conventional finite element, the following points are considered. Fig. 5
Convergence of the present (solid line) and conventional (dotted line) elements in free vibration analysis of a rotating cantilever beam

list-item.p: The original axially FG tapered beam is modelled as an assembly of several uniform homogeneous beam elements.
Within each beam element, the values of cross-sectional area, moment of inertia, modulus of elasticity, mass density, and centrifugal force are constant and equal to their respective maxima.
The Hermite cubic shape functions are selected to interpolate the displacement field along each beam element.

sec.p: It is observed in Fig. 5 that the present element converges rapidly to the accurate results. This point could be addressed to the selection of appropriate shape functions. For the following numerical examples, the beam is divided into 40 equal length elements.

sec.title: 4.2 Validation
sec.p: In this section, the results predicted by the present element are verified against those in the literature.

Consider a non-rotating uniform beam with unit length in which the mass density and modulus of elasticity vary in polynomial form respectively as
The fundamental frequency is determined for different boundary conditions using the present element. The results are tabulated in Table 1, where a good agreement is observed in comparison with those in the literature. Table 1

The present formulation can be used for analysis of beams with an arbitrary variation of material properties along the beam axis. Consider a non-rotating uniform beam made of aluminum and zirconia whose material properties vary along beam axis as
in which ξ=x¯/l, α is the non-homogeneity parameter and the subscripts 1 and 2 refer to the properties of the material at ξ=0 and ξ=1, respectively. Two different cases are considered as follows.

list-item.p: Case 1: The beam is Al rich near ξ=0 and ZrO2 rich near ξ=1.
Case 2: The beam is ZrO2 rich near ξ=0 and Al rich near ξ=1.

sec.title: 4.3 Effects of material non-homogeneity
sec.p:
Consider a uniform axially FG beam with δ=0 rotating at η=5. It is assumed that the FG material follows the power law given in equation (14). The effect of non-homogeneity parameter on the first five dimensionless natural frequencies of this beam for different boundary conditions is illuminated in Table 3. It is observed that the natural frequencies of a homogeneous beam are higher than those of a non-homogenous one except for the C–F and P–F boundary conditions. It is observed that the variation of the fundamental frequency with respect to the increase in non-homogeneity parameter is different for the six boundary conditions. For the beams attached to the hub with a clamped condition, the fundamental frequency decreases with non-homogeneity parameter; while it increases for P–P boundary condition. The fundamental frequency for P–F boundary condition remains unchanged with the increase in n. It is observed that the increase in non-homogeneity parameter does not have a monotonic effect on the fundamental frequency of a P–C beam. It is worthy to note that the higher frequencies show an increasing trend with the increase in the non-homogeneity parameter. Table 3

sec.title: 4.4 Effects of taper ratio
sec.p: It can be verified that the natural frequencies for all types of boundary conditions decrease with the taper ratio with some exceptions including the fundamental frequency for C–F and P–F boundary conditions where the former shows an increasing trend and the latter remains unchanged. These effects could also be observed for homogeneous rotating beams [23–25]. For m=2, it is observed that the second frequency parameter tends to increase at high taper ratios for C–F and P–F boundary conditions. Moreover, Shahba et al. [34] have recently reported that the frequency parameters for axially FG Timoshenko beams with the same type of material distributions decrease, except for some cases, with taper ratio.

The first three normalized mode shapes of the beam with taper ratios c=0, 0.5 are given in Fig. 6(a) to (f) for m=2. The effects of taper ratio onmode shape could be clearly observed. It is interesting to know that the first mode shapes of P–F rotating tapered beam are identical for the two taper ratios; therefore, the corresponding frequencies are identical, as well. In fact, the first mode shapes of P–F rotating tapered beam are identical for any taper ratios. This could be addressed to the fact that a P–F beam undergoes a rigid body motion which is reflected by the first mode shape and this rigid body motion is not susceptible to the changes in the beam properties such as non-homogeneity and variation of cross-sectional area and moment of inertia. Due to this rigid body motion, the fundamental natural frequency of a P–F beam is similar to the rotating speed, as observed in Tables 3 to 5. Fig. 6
The first three normalized mode shapes (solid line, c=0; dotted line, c=0.5) of an axially rotating tapered beam with η=2, δ=0, and m=n=2. Boundary conditions: (a) P–P, (b) P–F, (c) P–C, (d) C–C, (e) C–P, and (f) C–F

sec.title: 4.5 Effects of rotating speed, hub radius, and tip mass
sec.p: In order to interpret the effects of tip mass on the natural frequencies, first, it is necessary to know how the tip mass is incorporated into the formulation. The presence of tip mass has two paradoxical effects on the vibration characteristics as follows.

list-item.p: Due to the rotation of the beam about Z axis, the tip mass is also subject to a centrifugal force equal to MΩ2(R+l). In other words, MΩ2(R+l) should be added to equation (2) while calculating the centrifugal force at an arbitrary point of the beam. Due to this effect, it can be already verified that the tip mass has a stiffening effect on the vibration characteristics of rotating beams by increasing the centrifugal force acting on the system.

Ignoring the rotary inertia of the tip mass, the tip mass should be added to the element of the mass matrix related to the transverse displacement of the tip. As a result, the tip mass introduces a softening effect by increasing the total mass of the system.

sec.p: For C–C, C–P, P–C, and P–P boundary conditions, the transverse displacement at the tip is zero; thus, the softening effect of tip mass does not play a role in free vibration analysis and only the stiffening effect is dominant. Therefore, the natural frequencies for these boundary conditions increase with the tip mass parameter. It is observed that the softening effect is more pronounced in comparison with the stiffening effect for the C–F and P–F boundary conditions; therefore, the natural frequencies decrease with the tip mass ratio. Furthermore, it is verified that the fundamental frequency for the P–F boundary condition for δ=0 is not susceptible to the changes in the tip mass ratio.

sec.title: 5 CONCLUSION
sec.p: Free vibration analysis of rotating axially FG tapered beams is carried out using a finite-element approach. The element takes advantage of shape functions, which capture the effects of variable cross-section, centrifugal force, and the gradation of material along the beam element. It was verified that the idea of BDFs could be efficiently employed in analysis of axially FG beam. Free vibration analysis was performed for different six boundary conditions. The effects of material non-homogeneity, taper ratio, rotating speed, hub radius, and tip mass were investigated.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: The financial support provided by the Vice Chancellor for Research at University of Tehran [grant no. 8102033/1/02] is gratefully acknowledged.

sec.p: In this appendix, the BDFs are briefly introduced and computed. Then, it is shown how the shape functions could be derived in terms of BDFs.

sec.title: DefinitionofBDFs
sec.p: BDFs have pure mechanical concepts and could be defined as

bv1: Transverse displacement of the free end of a free–clamped beam due to a unit lateral load at distance x in the presence of an arbitrarily varying axial load, as shown in Fig. 7(a). Fig. 7
Definitions of BDFs: (a) bv1, (b) bθ1, (c) bv2, and (d) bθ2
bθ1: Bending rotation of the free end of a free–clamped beam due to a unit lateral load at distance x in the presence of an arbitrarily varying axial load, as shown in Fig. 7(b).
bv2: Transverse displacement of the free end of a clamped–free beam due to a unit lateral load at distance x in the presence of an arbitrarily varying axial load, as shown in Fig. 7(c).
bθ2: Bending rotation of the free end of a clamped–free beam due to a unit load at distance x in the presence of an arbitrarily varying axial load, as shown in Fig. 7(d).
Using the reciprocal theorem, each BDF has an equivalent definition which could be defined as follows.

bv1: Transverse displacement at distance x due to a unit lateral load at the free end of a free–clamped beam in the presence of an arbitrarily varying axial load, as shown in Fig. 8(a). Fig. 8
Equivalent definitions of BDFs: (a) bv1, (b) bθ1, (c) bv2, and (d) bθ2
bθ1: Transverse displacement at distance x due to a unit moment at the free end of a free–clamped beam in the presence of an arbitrarily varying axial load, as shown in Fig. 8(b).
bv2: Transverse displacement at distance x due to a unit lateral load at the free end of a clamped–free beam in the presence of an arbitrarily varying axial load, as shown in Fig. 8(c).
bθ2: Transverse displacement at distance x due to a unit moment at the free end of a clamped–free beam in the presence of an arbitrarily varying axial load, as shown in Fig. 8(d).

sec.title: Computation of BDFs
sec.p: Based on the equivalent definition of BDFs, they are the transverse displacement of the free end of a cantilever beam due to either a unit nodal lateral load or bending moment in the presence of an arbitrarily varying axial load, here centrifugal force.Therefore, each BDF could be obtained by solving the governing differential equation, i.e. equation (3).
Considering the dimensionless coordinate ξ=xL, the transverse displacement, flexural rigidity, andcentrifugal force are assumed to be, respectively, as
Using power-series method to solve the governing differential equation, the following recurrence relation is obtained

Using this recurrence relation, transverse displacement W(x) is explicitly derived in terms of the four terms namely W0,W1,W2, and W3 as (19) where fi (i=1,2,3,4) are the fundamental solutions of equation (3) and W could be determined for each BDF by imposing the appropriate boundary conditions. Based on the equivalent definition of BDFs in Fig. 8, the boundary conditions for each BDF are
Moreover, the bending rotation, bending moments, and shear force are, respectively, given as

sec.title: Newshapefunctions
sec.p:
Consider a general tapered beam subjected to transverse load q(ξ) and varying axial force T(ξ), as shown in Fig. 9. Decomposing the original system into two statically determinate systems and using the superposition principle, the unknown support reactions could be obtained. The nodal displacements at the free end namely J in Fig. 9(b) could be easily derived in terms of BDFs as Fig. 9
General non-prismatic beam decomposed into statically determinate beams
The nodal displacements at J in Fig. 9(c) are obtained as
where FJJ is the nodal flexibility of the right end. Scrutinizing the equivalent definition of BDFs, the nodal flexibility matrices could be derived in terms of BDFs as
